title: The Power of Diversity (Tighty Whities Experiment) 1/3

tasks.task: Conduct a field experiment on the effects of corn and soybean rotations on soil health and nitrous oxide emissions.
subtasks: Set up experimental plots with two rotation types: a two-year corn and soybean rotation and a four-year rotation (four-year corn, pea, winter wheat, soybean) for 16 years.
Monitor nitrous oxide emissions from each plot, noting 25% lower emissions in the four-year rotation.
Measure soil organic matter, which is 25% higher in the four-year rotation compared to the two-year rotation.
Observe soybean yield increases (25% higher) in the four-year rotation compared to the two-year rotation.
Compare root exudates, diversity, and architecture between different rotation plots to understand underlying mechanisms.

tasks.task: Present "underwear experiment" to demonstrate soil decomposition rates.
subtasks: Use undergarments (e.g., t-shirts) representing soil layers.
Compare decomposition rates of different materials (e.g., cotton vs. synthetic fibers) over time to simulate organic matter decomposition.
Illustrate the rapid decomposition of synthetic materials versus slower decomposition of natural materials, analogous to the breakdown of crop residues in conventional versus diverse rotations.
Relay studies showing quicker decomposition in simpler systems (e.g., two-year rotation) versus slower decomposition (and thus more beneficial residues) in more diverse systems (four-year rotation).
